title: ThisȱisȱaȱvariationȱonȱtheȱthemeȱofȱtheȱChristianȱknightȱfallingȱinȱloveȱwithȱanȱenamoredȱSaracen princess,ȱwhichȱisȱcommonplaceȱinȱtheȱOldȱFrenchȱepic.ȱTheȱclassicȱexampleȱcomesȱfromȱLaȱPrise d’Orange,ȱinȱwhichȱOrableȱfallsȱinȱloveȱwithȱGuillaumeȱFierebrace.ȱSeeȱSharonȱKinoshita,ȱ“The PoliticsȱofȱCourtlyȱLove:ȱLaȱPriseȱd’OrangeȱandȱtheȱconversionȱofȱtheȱSaracenȱQueen,”ȱRomanic Review,ȱ86,ȱ2ȱ(1995):ȱ265–87;ȱCharlesȱA.ȱKnudson,ȱ“LeȱthèmeȱdeȱlaȱprincesseȱsarrasineȱdansȱLaȱPrise d’Orange,”ȱRomanceȱPhilology,ȱ22ȱ(1969):ȱ449–62;ȱandȱmoreȱgenerally,ȱLynnȱTarteȱRamey,ȱ“Role Models?ȱSaracenȱWomenȱinȱMedievalȱFrenchȱEpic,”ȱRomanceȱNotes,ȱ41,ȱ2ȱ(2001):ȱ131–41.ȱSeeȱalso Albrechtȱ Classen,ȱ “Confrontationȱ withȱ theȱ Foreignȱ Worldȱ ofȱ theȱ East:ȱ Saracenȱ Princessesȱ in MedievalȱGermanȱNarratives,”ȱOrbisȱLitterarumȱ53ȱ(1998):ȱ277–95

title: CenturyȱCastile:ȱToledanȱWidowsȱandȱPatternsȱofȱPatronage,”ȱ177–94.ȱNowȱseeȱalsoȱBrittaȬJuliane Kruse,ȱWitwen:ȱKulturgeschichteȱeinesȱStandesȱinȱSpätmittelalterȱundȱFrüherȱNeuzeitȱ(BerlinȱandȱNew York:ȱ deȱ Gruyter,ȱ 2007)ȱ Forȱ anȱ overviewȱ ofȱ issuesȱ surroundingȱ womenȱ andȱ patronage,ȱ see CynthiaȱLawrence,ȱ“Introduction,”ȱWomenȱandȱArtȱinȱEarlyȱModernȱEurope:ȱPatrons,ȱCollectors,ȱand Connoisseurs,ȱed.ȱCythinaȱLawrenceȱ(UniversityȱPark,ȱPA:ȱPennsylvaniaȱStateȱUniversityȱPress, 1997),ȱ1–20.ȱThisȱcollectionȱcontainsȱnumerousȱarticlesȱrelevantȱtoȱissuesȱconcerningȱwomen’s patronageȱactivitiesȱinȱtheȱcontextȱofȱfuneraryȱorȱconventȱsettings.ȱSee,ȱforȱexample,ȱAlexandra Carpino,ȱ “Margaretȱ ofȱ Austria’sȱ Funeraryȱ Complexȱ atȱ Brou,”ȱ 37–52ȱ andȱ Marilynȱ R.ȱ Dunn, “SpiritualȱPhilanthropists:ȱWomenȱasȱConventȱPatronsȱinȱSeicentoȱRome,”ȱ154–88.ȱCarolynȱValone pointsȱtoȱwomen’sȱchoiceȱofȱarchitectureȱasȱaȱmechanismȱforȱtheȱpublicȱexpressionȱofȱpersonal concernsȱinȱ“RomanȱMatronsȱasȱPatrons:ȱVariousȱViewsȱofȱtheȱCloisterȱWall,”ȱTheȱCranniedȱWall

container-title: Oldȱ Ageȱ inȱ theȱ Middleȱ Agesȱ andȱ theȱ Renaissance
title: ALLISONȱP.ȱCOUDERTȱreceivedȱherȱPhDȱfromȱtheȱWarburgȱInstitute,ȱUniversity ofȱLondon.ȱSheȱisȱcurrentlyȱtheȱPaulȱandȱMarieȱCastelfrancoȱChairȱinȱtheȱReligious StudiesȱProgramȱatȱtheȱUniversityȱofȱCaliforniaȱatȱDavis.ȱHerȱpublishedȱbooks includeȱLeibnizȱandȱtheȱKabbalahȱ(Dordrecht:ȱKluwer,ȱ1995)ȱandȱTheȱImpactȱofȱthe Kabbalahȱinȱtheȱ17thCentury:ȱTheȱLifeȱandȱThoughtȱofȱFrancisȱMercuryȱvanȱHelmont, 1614–1698ȱ(LeidenȱandȱBoston:ȱBrill,ȱ1999).ȱAmongȱherȱrecentȱarticlesȱare,ȱ“Ange duȱfoyerȱouȱidoleȱdeȱperversité:ȱésotérismeȱauȱfeminineȱauȱXIXeȱsiècle,”ȱPolitica Hermeticaȱ20ȱ(2006):ȱ29–47ȱandȱ“TheȱSulzbachȱJubilee:ȱOldȱAgeȱinȱEarlyȱModern Europeȱ andȱ America,”ȱ

STEPHANIEȱ FINKȱ DEȱ BACKERȱ isȱ anȱ assistantȱ professorȱ ofȱ earlyȱ modern EuropeanȱhistoryȱatȱArizonaȱStateȱUniversity.ȱHerȱworkȱonȱCastilianȱwomenȱhas beenȱpublishedȱinȱinterdisciplinaryȱcollections,ȱincludingȱWidowhoodȱandȱVisual CultureȱinȱEarlyȱModernȱEuropeȱ(2003)ȱandȱPowerȱandȱGenderȱinȱRenaissanceȱSpain: EightȱWomenȱofȱtheȱMendozaȱFamily,ȱ1450–1650ȱ(2004).ȱTheȱarticleȱinȱthisȱcollection isȱpartȱofȱaȱfullerȱstudy,ȱWidowhood,ȱAutonomy,ȱandȱPowerȱinȱEarlyȱModernȱSpain, forthcomingȱfromȱBrill.ȱSheȱisȱcurrentlyȱengagedȱinȱtwoȱnewȱprojects,ȱWomenȱinȱthe HabsburgȱKingdomsȱofȱNaplesȱandȱSicily:ȱNegotiatingȱEmpireȱacrossȱtheȱMediterranean, 1516–1700ȱandȱaȱcoȬauthoredȱstudy,ȱLaȱDamaȱSebastian:ȱStagingȱEnlightenmentȱin EighteenthȬCenturyȱMadrid
